quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Evan is the founder of CORE Sciences, which teaches companies and individuals how our brains actually work, and through that lens, how to more effectively work with other people on teams, how to build better products, how to grow your business, and how to make smarter and faster decisions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Sets up a practical, brain-science lens for improving teamwork, product building, growth, and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Evan is a four-time founder, including founding a company called Satellite, which is the fourth largest analytics product on the internet today, which was acquired by Adobe where he later ran product strategy and innovation for Adobe's digital business.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete credibility/data point about Evan’s experience and the scale of a product he built.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Evan shares a simple way to understand how our brains work, and through that framework, how we can get better at vision work, influence, running meetings, having more focus and building better and more productive relationships with our colleagues.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Previews a “simple way” framework tied directly to actionable workplace skills (vision, influence, meetings, focus, relationships).

quotes.topic_title: Brain as departments: choosing thinking pathways
quotes.text: I think of it like the brain is like a college campus that has different departments in it, and your brain has a science department responsible for open-minded experimentation.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Introduces a practical mental model for deliberately choosing different “modes” of thinking based on the problem.

quotes.topic_title: Brain as departments: choosing thinking pathways
quotes.text: It has an art department in it responsible for creative boundless thinking. It has a history department designed for looking stuff up that you already know.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Clarifies distinct thinking pathways (creative vs. recall) that practitioners can intentionally route questions through.

quotes.topic_title: Brain as departments: choosing thinking pathways
quotes.text: Where we're stuck largely is most people rely on their history department way too much.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Calls out a common failure mode—defaulting to memory/precedent instead of exploration—useful for diagnosing team decision patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Brain as departments: choosing thinking pathways
quotes.text: That's because the brain is actually built to conserve energy, and that's the lowest energy form of generating an answer to a question that the brain can pull off.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Explains why people default to “lookup mode,” giving a concrete lever for changing behavior (expect effort when switching modes).

quotes.topic_title: Brain as departments: choosing thinking pathways
quotes.text: If you instead send things to the more experimental, open-minded science department, the more creative art department, the humanities department of your compassion, et cetera, you get totally different answers.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: deliberately reframe problems to trigger different cognitive “departments” and unlock better solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We all know that your website shouldn't be a static asset, it should be a dynamic part of your strategy that drives conversions, that's business 101.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Reframes the website as an actively managed growth lever rather than a one-time deliverable.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Here's a number for you, 54% of leaders say web updates take too long.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Quantifies how common slow web iteration is, helping justify investment in faster tooling/processes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can also be more intentional with these pathways, and that's a big component of self-awareness is to know what are my preferences and then am I actually letting those preferences take over in the situation or might be more intentional steering down the pathways to activate these best regions and systems of the brain.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Offers a practical self-awareness method: notice default mental preferences and deliberately choose a better cognitive “pathway” for the situation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The simplest way to keep track of the systems is there's three, there's three really big ones.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Introduces a simplifying framework for understanding brain systems by grouping them into three major categories.

quotes.topic_title: Three brain systems: safety, reward, purpose
quotes.text: You can also be more intentional with these pathways, and that's a big component of self-awareness is to know what are my preferences and then am I actually letting those preferences take over in the situation or might be more intentional steering down the pathways to activate these best regions and systems of the brain.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Actionable self-awareness lever: notice default mental pathways and intentionally shift to more effective ones.

quotes.topic_title: Three brain systems: safety, reward, purpose
quotes.text: If you're in a meeting, a practical everyday situation, and you're exposed to a statement that makes you feel unsafe, your objective now actually isn't to contribute to the meeting productively anymore.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing of meeting dysfunction: perceived threat silently changes the brain’s goal away from collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Three brain systems: safety, reward, purpose
quotes.text: When you hear people say, "That's not my job." That's actually the reward system speaking, saying, "I get rewarded for the things in this list and this thing that you're talking about is not on my reward list and I therefore am not interested in it."
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Practical diagnostic for motivation problems: “not my job” signals a transactional reward-frame mismatch.

quotes.topic_title: Three brain systems: safety, reward, purpose
quotes.text: if you understand the impact of the thing that you're doing and you understand and care about the people that are impacted by your actions, those are the conditions for purpose, and that can be really big.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Clear, usable definition of purpose that leaders can operationalize by clarifying impact and affected people.

quotes.topic_title: Three brain systems: safety, reward, purpose
quotes.text: I think it's approachable, it's simple. It's like, we can all understand, is my safety reward or purpose system active right now? What is my level of focus? What level of connection with reality, reason and imagination do I have right now? Then there's your output as a human or as a team, and all these things are like levers we can pull, which is super fun.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A practical checklist/mental model for diagnosing and improving individual or team performance in the moment.

quotes.topic_title: Why people work differently: personality and self-awareness
quotes.text: Maybe one of the worst pieces of propaganda that people walk around with in their minds is the phrase we're more similar than we are different.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A contrarian reframe that explains why workplace friction often comes from underestimating real personality differences.

quotes.topic_title: Why people work differently: personality and self-awareness
quotes.text: When in fact, we should probably be building the muscle that we have the capacity to get along with people that are extremely different than we are.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Actionable advice to treat cross-style collaboration as a skill to deliberately develop rather than a compatibility problem.

quotes.topic_title: Why people work differently: personality and self-awareness
quotes.text: We often use the metaphor in our training of culinary school that we're more culinary school for human performance instead of cooking class.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for focusing on underlying principles of human behavior rather than rote management tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Why people work differently: personality and self-awareness
quotes.text: If you don't know who you are and you think that the universe resembles you, then you're going to get super lost in that broader spectrum.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A self-awareness principle that warns against projecting your own preferences onto others when working across different styles.

quotes.topic_title: Why people work differently: personality and self-awareness
quotes.text: They're just all imperfect ways of measuring personality, but also, useful despite the fact that they're imperfect and especially useful if you take a growth mentality instead of a justification mentality to reading them.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A practical methodology for using personality tools as inputs for behavior change rather than excuses for fixed traits.

quotes.topic_title: Teams as habitats: environment shapes performance
quotes.text: You're actually in a habitat as a company and your team is like a habitat. I think of companies and teams, almost like little terrariums that we're inside of, and is this terrarium set up with sand and a heat lamp and we're a bunch of frogs, like we're going to turn into frog bacon, simply because we're in this habitat? A lot of it is you want to actually create a habitat or an environment that's predisposed to high-functioning thinking and high-functioning interaction between people.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Introduces the “teams as habitats/terrariums” mental model and makes environment design a primary lever for performance.

quotes.topic_title: Teams as habitats: environment shapes performance
quotes.text: Because if the habitat is working against all of you to begin with, then all the hand-to-hand combat that's going to show up is actually largely a function of you just being in this heat lamp, dry, devoid of life, devoid of productive ways to grapple.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Reframes team conflict as an environmental symptom rather than an individual failing, implying leaders should fix conditions first.

quotes.topic_title: Teams as habitats: environment shapes performance
quotes.text: There's a great quote, I think Dan Pink has summarized the problem better than anybody when he said, "There's a mismatch between what science knows and what business does."
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Provides a diagnostic lens for organizational dysfunction: compare current practices to what behavioral science says works.

quotes.topic_title: Teams as habitats: environment shapes performance
quotes.text: You can almost look at this as an equation of science knows minus what your business does equals dysfunction.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Turns the “science vs. business” mismatch into a simple, memorable methodology for identifying what to change.

quotes.topic_title: Teams as habitats: environment shapes performance
quotes.text: There's a whole list of stuff from very deep to very tactical of things we can do differently that reduce the gap between what you're doing and what science knows and the dysfunction just shrinks and shrinks and shrinks as you do those things.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Action-oriented takeaway: systematically closing the science-to-practice gap reduces dysfunction over time.

quotes.topic_title: Meetings: priming before decision-making
quotes.text: Here's something super tactical, which is, meetings, generally speaking, are a combination of priming and decision making, if you look at meetings through the lens of the phases that they are.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Introduces a simple two-phase framework (priming → decision-making) for diagnosing and improving meeting effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Meetings: priming before decision-making
quotes.text: A lot of meetings skip the priming step altogether. They launched directly into decision making.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode that creates misalignment and conflict by jumping to decisions without shared context and intent.

quotes.topic_title: Meetings: priming before decision-making
quotes.text: People save anywhere from a full half of a day to a full day per week of work as a result of just cleaning up the way they're using meetings.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Quantifies the potential ROI of improving meeting design and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Meetings: priming before decision-making
quotes.text: Other meetings get the priming and the decision-making backwards.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Calls out a subtler anti-pattern: doing alignment too late, after conflict has already surfaced.

quotes.topic_title: Meetings: priming before decision-making
quotes.text: If somebody is trying to make the decision with speed in mind and another person is trying to make the decision with accuracy in mind, it is completely inevitable that they're about to have a cat fight in the meeting.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Shows why explicitly aligning on principles (e.g., speed vs. accuracy) prevents unresolvable tactical debates.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy and vision: believable vs inconceivable ideas
quotes.text: What you'll encounter in life, in your mind, is ideas are swirling. Whether you're generating those ideas or other people are, is your brain is going to sort those ideas into believed, believable, kind of conceivable and inconceivable.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A practical mental model for diagnosing why strategy/vision discussions stall: people are sorting the same idea into different belief-buckets.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy and vision: believable vs inconceivable ideas
quotes.text: This is why minds struggle with strategy and with vision, is that every mind based on personality we talked about earlier, that line of demarcation between believed, we all have different lived experience, so the more experience you have, the more believed you have.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Explains a hidden driver of misalignment: different lived experience shifts what feels “already true,” changing how hard an idea is to accept.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy and vision: believable vs inconceivable ideas
quotes.text: Big part of self-awareness is where our unbelievable threshold begins, where our believable threshold ends.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Actionable self-check for leaders: identify the point where you stop evaluating ideas on merit and start rejecting them reflexively.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy and vision: believable vs inconceivable ideas
quotes.text: A lot of the vision thinking and dialogue that happens inside of businesses directly activates people's inconceivable response without any self-awareness that, that's a personal problem, not a objective problem.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing: “this is impossible” is often a subjective reaction, not an objective assessment—so treat it as a signal to test, not debate.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy and vision: believable vs inconceivable ideas
quotes.text: If you are low in openness, your brain essentially has abstract, creative, intellectual, complex thinking wired to the pain systems of the brain.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A concrete personality-based explanation for why some teammates viscerally resist abstract strategy work—and why socializing this can reduce conflict.

quotes.topic_title: Openness trait and vulnerability to reduce friction
quotes.text: But it gets a little less scary when we consider how much scarier our alternatives are. I can pretend to hide this, that's my other option, or I can not hide it, be a Tasmanian devil, and then be unapologetic. So those are your three options, and when you realize I can be vulnerable, I can attempt to hide it, or I can be unapologetic, those other two options are ruinous compared to vulnerability.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A practical decision framework for choosing vulnerability by comparing it against two worse alternatives (hiding or being unapologetically abrasive).

quotes.topic_title: Openness trait and vulnerability to reduce friction
quotes.text: I mean, because if you think about these ideas as pegs in holes, we're going to take a creativity shaped peg and try to put it through a more pragmatic shaped hole, there's a translation problem there, and it's a huge burden.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for why teams waste time when abstract ideas must be translated into “pragmatic” language for low-openness stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: Openness trait and vulnerability to reduce friction
quotes.text: Well, if the idea is inherently generating nth order effects instead of first order effects, like what is the ROI of having fresh flowers in the lobby of a Four Seasons hotel? There's two possibilities for the Four Seasons, they either have an answer to that question which satisfies the pragmatic shaped hole, or they have said in their habitat, we don't ask those types of questions because they're a huge waste of time.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how ROI questioning can be counterproductive for ideas with second- and third-order effects—and how strong cultures preempt that trap.

quotes.topic_title: Openness trait and vulnerability to reduce friction
quotes.text: And that team, because they got stuck in the translation phase instead of the experimentation phase, has a huge disadvantage in the market
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: A sharp warning that over-indexing on justification/translation delays learning and creates competitive disadvantage versus faster experimenters.

quotes.topic_title: Openness trait and vulnerability to reduce friction
quotes.text: So if you can give me something concrete, I'm more comfortable, but at this point I have to maybe move into a lot of trust, and trust may be my alternative to agreement, right?
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for low-openness leaders: ask for concreteness, and when that’s not possible, explicitly switch from “agreement” to “trust” to keep decisions moving.

quotes.topic_title: Can people change traits? Focus on team effect
quotes.text: Personally I'm more concerned with the effect on teams than on people, because if you look at this through the... I've been a four time founder, and if I look at this through how is my company working? How are my teams working? I don't need all the individuals to get to perfect, I need, especially in cases where there's this translation issue where a team is working on something and some part of that team is saying, "Let's stop here and let's dwell here." If they can move enough that the team, the effect on the team is now freed up, that's what we really feel as a business.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Reframes personal development as optimizing team throughput rather than perfecting individuals, with a concrete example of unblocking a team stuck “dwelling.”

quotes.topic_title: Can people change traits? Focus on team effect
quotes.text: Self-awareness is actually kind of the key, and self-awareness and self-consciousness, the difference here is that self-awareness is simply being intentional with your brain, whereas self-consciousness is being worried about your brain.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Provides a crisp mental model distinguishing productive intentionality from unproductive insecurity.

quotes.topic_title: Can people change traits? Focus on team effect
quotes.text: We don't want people to be worried about their brains and insecure, we just want you to say, this is a situation in which my brain can work this way, and this is a situation where I want to push myself.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for situationally adapting behavior: notice your default mode, then deliberately stretch when the context calls for it.

quotes.topic_title: Can people change traits? Focus on team effect
quotes.text: You're always going to have instinctive responses about risk and fear and uncertainty and doubt and need for data, and all these types of things, but then your intellect can come in and watch that part of your brain thinking and say, you're super worried about the risk of this, but it's actually pretty low stakes for us to jump in and try.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Offers a practical “instinct vs intellect” method: let intellect audit instinctive reactions and recalibrate based on stakes.

quotes.topic_title: Can people change traits? Focus on team effect
quotes.text: It doesn't matter if we change your motivations, if your choice of behavior and your underlying motivation can be different from each other, that's awesome, those people are super.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway that you don’t need to change what you feel—just decouple it from what you do to perform well.

quotes.topic_title: Traits affecting vision: openness and conscientiousness
quotes.text: Openness is the biggest one because it is essentially your tolerance of vision and strategy, and the lower that is, the lower you will tolerate the abstract pieces of the puzzle, for sure.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Defines openness as a core driver of strategic thinking and a practical self-diagnostic for why vision work feels hard.

quotes.topic_title: Traits affecting vision: openness and conscientiousness
quotes.text: The outlandish and purely creative and rules-breaking components of strategy and vision, lack of precedence, those types of things.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Clarifies what “openness” actually looks like in strategy work: comfort with novelty, ambiguity, and precedent-breaking ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Traits affecting vision: openness and conscientiousness
quotes.text: Now the other thing to look out for is as your conscientiousness rises, which is essentially your desire to be efficient, effective, busy, not waste time.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Highlights a second trait to monitor—conscientiousness—as a hidden constraint on time-intensive strategy exploration.

quotes.topic_title: Traits affecting vision: openness and conscientiousness
quotes.text: it's objectively great to be a conscientious person, there are so many benefits, until we have to waste time productively, or we have to break order in organization.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Counterintuitive point that a strength (conscientiousness) can become a liability when strategy requires “productive waste” and disruption.

quotes.topic_title: Traits affecting vision: openness and conscientiousness
quotes.text: And one of the rituals that I find myself around a lot was the ritual of saying, we can't talk about this for the rest of our lives.
quotes.speaker: Evan LaPointe
quotes.context: Concrete post-acquisition meeting example of how efficiency pressure can prematurely shut down necessary strategic discussion.
